description: Borrowed from French toxique, from Late Latin toxicus (“poisoned”), from Latin toxicum (“poison”), from Ancient Greek τοξικόν (toxikón) [φάρμακον (phármakon)] ("poison for use on arrows"), from τοξικός (toxikós, “pertaining to arrows or archery”), from τόξον (tóxon, “bow”).

adjectives.description: toxic (comparative more toxic, superlative most toxic)

entries.meaning: (toxicology, pharmacology) Having a chemical nature that is harmful to health or lethal if consumed or otherwise entering into the body in sufficient quantities.
examples: Tobacco smoke contains many toxic substances.

entries.meaning: (medicine) Appearing grossly unwell; characterised by serious, potentially life-threatening compromise in the respiratory, circulatory or other body systems.
examples: The child appeared toxic on arrival at the hospital.
a toxic environment that promoted bullying

entries.meaning: (figurative, of a person) Hateful or strongly antipathetic.
examples: It is not good to be around toxic people.
